Laws
3. Laws

The Scientific Revolution ushered in a new type of knowledge, based in
laws of nature. Kant’s natural philosophy thus gave that notion
a central place. In particular, he analyzed it, he used it to single
out certain laws as fundamental, and he weaved it into his picture of
systematic science. We go over these aspects in turn.

Nomic import. For the Critical Kant, a law is a
judgment, or proposition, that is necessary and
imposed by a faculty of the mind—specifically, the
understanding or reason. In the realm of theoretical knowledge, laws
determine the object they govern. (In contrast, laws of practical
reason bind their subjects, by mandating an action or a maxim for
behavior.) There are several classes of Kantian laws: transcendental
(e.g., the pure principles of the understanding); metaphysical (such
as his three laws of mechanics); and empirical (in particular, the
laws of chemistry).

The above picture, which Watkins 2019 articulates and defends in
detail, gives center stage to the thought that laws are partially
grounded in the natures of knowers like us—specifically, in the
faculties (and their a priori structures) that Kant investigated in
the First Critique. Other construals leave this key element out,
and rely on other resources from his theoretical philosophy. Some have
proposed a ‘necessitarian’ account, in which Kantian laws
are grounded in the natures of the things they are about, thus
natures—the bodies’ essential properties and
powers—are their necessity-makers (Messina 2017, Massimi 2017,
Engelhard 2018). Others think that certain propositions, or judgments,
count as laws in virtue of their place in a best-system ordering of
our knowledge as directed by Kant’s ideas of reason (see, e.g.,
Kitcher 1986 or Breitenbach 2018). These two interpretive approaches
turn Kant into a precursor of two major contemporary notions of law,
by Fred Dretske and David Lewis, respectively. Watkins argues that, if
read carefully, Kant in fact offers a view that combines the
strengths of the two pictures above: it retains the necessitarian
dimension while emphasizing the role of our acts—of us qua
spontaneous epistemic subjects—in regard to nature as the object
of unified experience (Watkins 2019, esp. Chapter 2).

In philosophy of physics, Kant privileged three laws: Conservation of
Mass, the Law of Inertia, and the Equality of Action-Reaction. He
regarded them as fundamental for mechanics as he understood it, viz.
qua theory of momentum exchanges, or ‘communication of
motion.’ And, these laws lie closest—explanatorily and
evidentially—to the Analogies of Experience, the most general
principles of theoretical knowledge, in his system. Specifically, the
Second Analogy is a key premise in his derivation of his ‘second
mechanical law.’

Though somewhat intermittently, Kant reflected as well on empirical
laws, viz. nomic judgments that govern some restricted class of
objects or properties given a posteriori. He thought that, to count as
a rational science, a body of knowledge must include empirical laws
systematically connected. In the last decade, this long-neglected
aspect of his doctrine has began to receive the attention it deserves.
Scholarship has tended to concentrate on two main aspects. One is
Kant’s basis for counting certain propositions as empirical
laws. Some see them as earning that status in virtue of their place in a
best-system organization of our knowledge; others think they become
laws at a certain stage in the process of inquiry (provided the
inquiry is guided by specific normative Kantian principles, e.g. his
Postulates of Empirical Thinking). The other aspect is whether
empirical laws count as knowable by Kant’s lights. Here too, the
field appears divided in two camps. Some think that, pace his positive
account of empirical laws, knowledge of them is beyond our reach (see,
for instance, Kreines 2017). Others have argued that, under the right
conditions, research can lead to the discovery of empirical laws in
that particular domain, e.g. chemical phenomena (see, for instance,
McNulty 2015 and Cooper 2023).

Hypotheses. Natural science after 1650 often relied
on ‘hypotheses,’ or knowledge claims for which evidence
was less than conclusive. In optics, electricity, magnetism, heat
science, chemistry, and natural history hypotheses were rampant.
Accordingly, some early-modern figures (e.g. Christian Wolff and
Emilie du Châtelet) developed doctrines to address this fact
about science then. Kant did too. In particular, he sought to identify
normative criteria for acceptable hypotheses, viz. thresholds that
candidate hypotheses must meet if theorizing from them is to count as
legitimate. He defended for three such criteria in his
‘Discipline of Pure Reason in regard to Hypotheses,’ a
part of the First Critique. The first is that a candidate hypothesis
has to be about things that are ‘really possible’ in
Kant’s sense; namely, spatio-temporal objects and
properties. (This rules out, for one, hypotheses about God being the
‘cause of gravity,’ which some Newtonians had peddled in
the early 1700s). The second is that a hypothesis must be about
objects and processes causally connected—more broadly,
connected via the categories of relation—to “that which is
actually given, and so is certain” (B798). Helpful studies of
Kant’s account of hypotheses in their scientific and
philosophical context are Leduc 2013, Vanzo 2013, McNulty 2015, Cooper
2023, and Demarest & van den Berg 2022.
